page.title: 01Craster-Fishing & Farmland
page.content: The rocky coastline runs NS, & half of this blockis sea. Craster Village has a population of c.350. There is a harbour with five fishing boats (called cobles) each manned by two men. They fish for crabs, lobsters, whitefish, sea-trout and salmon. A kippering shed operates from June to September smoking herring now bought by lorry from the west coast of Scotland. The coast is designated as "an ara of outstanding natural beauty" and visited by many touristes in the summer-mainly on day trips. A line of westward facing cliffs (called heughs) runs NS 500 metres from the sea. There is a medieval pele tower in the small hamlet of Dunstan and another at Craster Tower (continuously occupied by the family of that name since the 12th century): both lie about one kilometre west of Craster
